Support for 32 FP down to 16FX, 8FX, 2 (ternary) and 1 bit (binary) weights and activations to enable vector instructions.

We don't know the real-time use cases in coming future. Tensor flow has a node DecodeJpeg implementation to support this and is used in Inception V1.

We could drop node and similar nodes (resize, crop ...etc) in frontend if not needed, but that changes model inputs and lead additional effort to developer to add pre processing.

I was checking Qualcomm NPE SDK and they too support these kind of pre processing nodes.

Pls suggest.

Siva

I prefer this way, which make developers reduce effort to preprocess models. However, I know some tools don't support Tensorflow JPEGDecodes node. For example [tf-coreml](https://github.com/tf-coreml/tf-coreml) (Tensorflow to CoreML Converters), which will let developers preprocess tensorflow model manually. But I think if we can do it automatically like  Qualcomm NPE SDK, it is great.

@tqchen Do you mean the changes as below?

In topi/vision/reorg.py
```
def reorg(data, stride):
    """Reorg forward operators.

    Parameters
    ----------
    Input : tvm.Tensor
        4-D with shape [batch, in_channel, in_height, in_width]

    stride : int
        Stride value for reorganization

    Returns
    -------
    Output : tvm.Tensor
        4-D with shape [batch, out_channel, out_height, out_width]
    """
    batch, c_in, h_in, w_in = util.get_const_tuple(data.shape)
    out_c = int(c_in / (stride * stride))
    out = tvm.compute((batch, c_in, h_in, w_in), lambda b, k, j, i:
                      data[b * stride * stride,
                           (k % out_c) * stride * stride,
                           (j*stride + (k / out_c) / stride) * stride,
                           (i*stride + (k / out_c) % stride)],
                      tag="reorg")
    out_c = int(c_in * stride * stride)
    out_h = int(h_in / stride)
    out_w = int(w_in / stride)
    return transform.reshape(out, (batch, out_c, out_h, out_w))
```
should be changed to 
```
def reorg(data, stride):
    """Reorg forward operators.

    Parameters
    ----------
    Input : tvm.Tensor
        4-D with shape [batch, in_channel, in_height, in_width]

    stride : int
        Stride value for reorganization

    Returns
    -------
    Output : tvm.Tensor
        4-D with shape [batch, out_channel, out_height, out_width]
    """
    return cpp.vision.reorg(data, stride)
```
and similar way changes will happen for schedule also, where python schedule functions will call cpp schedule functions.
yes, just to minimize the overall maintenance effort for complex kernels

I agree that it is helpful to include the preprocessing pip-line. However, I think it is better to leave out the DecodeJpeg part because most of the cases the image could come with other coding format, it is easier to provide user with a tool to knock that part out.

Another reason is that decode jpg can only works well on CPU, which would in term hurt portability. So let us exclude the image decoding from the graph for now

@srkreddy1238 is it possible to update the front end to skip the decoding node? Most cases the picture may already comes from camera or decoded so it is still better in that way.  I propose we close this for now. The other kinds of input transformations are welcomed
Move nms under vision to be a standalone operator. Split multibox_detection into two operators, so that they can be compiled with different backend easily.

How ThreadPool work with the graph runtime? Associated with the compiled operator? I'm wondering if we can implement graph runtime in Rust?
Thanks for contribution, we can directly support relu6 via http://docs.tvmlang.org/api/python/topi.html#topi.clip so adding a new operator is not necessary

> wondering if we can implement graph runtime in Rust?

This is a most excellent idea! Not only would Rust solve the data race problem, it would also improve integration with SGX via [rust-sgx-sdk](https://github.com/baidu/rust-sgx-sdk). I've also noticed that it's very easy to break the system allocator in very subtle ways by incorrectly memsetting the structs used by the runtime.

I anticipate several challenges, though. A primary concern is C++/Rust interoperability (particularly w.r.t. dmlc-core). The officially-supported [`bindgen`](https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/rust-bindgen/cpp.html) utility doesn't handle C++ very well so everything would have to go through the C API, which might be unergonomic.

> How ThreadPool work with the graph runtime?

To answer your specific question, currently graph runtime doesn't directly interact with threads. The operators themselves call [`TVMBackendParallelLaunch`](https://github.com/myelin-ml/tvm/blob/master/src/runtime/thread_pool.cc#L330). This is problematic when there are multiple graph runtimes calling the same ops because launches simultaneously add work to the global work queue.

Can you say more on which piece of the eager initialization causes issues?

Basically, the following code paradigm no longer works

```python
no call into ROCM API before this
fork process using multiprocessing
use ROCM API
```

The above code sequence would work for CUDA and opencl because their states are lazily initialized. This could prevent some possible usages. In our case, we need to fork new process to provide isolation of session for RPC. Some deep learning libraries might start by using python's multi-processing to start new processes to load data(which don't need GPU) and then use GPU API, the eager initialization prevent us from doing that.

@bensander I am not sure which piece it is but should it should be part of hsa runtime. You should be able to reproduce this by crafting a program that forks at the beginning of program and then use ROCM API.

@adityaatluri  My guess is that such eager initialization was due to use of static global variable or something related to that, instead of using a static function that lazily initializes things in first call.
ref https://isocpp.org/wiki/faq/ctors#static-init-order
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/apps/rocm_rpc/README.md

Got it - we have seen this behavior in a few other situations but seems it is becoming more popular here.  IIRC the issue was related to mapping queues into user-space memory which breaks fork.  We had a couple solutions, let me follow up and see what we can do.
Refactored argsort to make the logic clear. Also added a more complicated test case.

Thanks for everyone who have pushed to last release cycle in the past three month. I would like to propose release of v0.3 on May 21th.  As usual, the current checklist will go into the release note, and we will move the unfinished ones into the roadmap of next release cycle.

Main contributors to the past release, see complete list [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/graphs/contributors?from=2018-02-01&to=2018-05-14&type=c) :
Thanks to all the contributors who makes the awesome progress

 Code Reviewers
- @zhreshold for reviewing many vision ops
- @Huyuwei topi operators
- @sxjscience for reviewing topi operators

TOPI:
- @merrymercy Mali GPU support
- @PariksheetPinjari909 topi vision ops, support for darknet operators 
- @yzhliu intel CPU optimization
- @kevinthesun Vision operators, initial ssd, nms operator support
- @dingobye Various great TOPI improvements for operator overloading
- @Huyuwei dilation support to conv
- @masahi Intel CPU topi
- @nishi-t  improvements in pooling 

Compiler:
- @nhynes SGX support
- @phisiart WebGL backend
- @alex-weaver C++ compiler support
- @kun-zh bug fix bound checking in code.
- @xqdan improvement low level schedule rewrite.
- @yidawang parallel runtime improvement
- @eqy AMD GPU backend improvements
- @Laurawly Initial improvements for intel GPU
- @cnuernber Improved runtime device stream API
Please reply to see if there is something we would like to merge in before tag v0.3

In general, i feel there should exist better algorithms than current take that break things down and redo it. We should be able to do everything in a single compute, cc @yzhliu @Huyuwei for further comment
@tqchen , all comments are handled...

We can implement the logic in python like this:

```python
def take(x, indices, axis=-1):
    in_len = len(x.shape)
    indices_len = len(indices.shape)
    out_len = in_len + indices_len - 1
    if axis < 0:
        axis = in_len + axis
    in_shape = get_const_tuple(x.shape)
    indices_shape = get_const_tuple(indices.shape)
    out_shape = in_shape[0:axis] + indices_shape + in_shape[axis+1:]
    def _compute(*out_index):
        index_along_axis = indices(*out_index[axis:(axis+indices_len)])
        in_index = out_index[0:axis] + (index_along_axis,) + out_index[axis+indices_len:]
        return x(*in_index)
    return tvm.compute(out_shape, _compute)
```
